content.title: Mitral Stenosis
content.summary: Mitral stenosis (MS) is narrowing of the mitral valve orifice obstructing blood flow from the left atrium to left ventricle during diastole. Rheumatic heart disease remains the primary cause worldwide. Chronic LA pressure elevation leads to LA enlargement, atrial fibrillation, pulmonary hypertension, and heart failure. Treatment involves diuretics, rate control, anticoagulation for AF, and intervention for symptomatic severe MS.
key_points: Rheumatic heart disease is the most common cause (globally); degenerative in developed countries
Normal MVA 4-6 cm²; Severe MS: MVA ≤1.5 cm² or mean gradient ≥10 mmHg
LA enlargement → Atrial fibrillation → Thromboembolism (anticoagulate all MS with AF)
Auscultation: Low-pitched diastolic rumble at apex with loud S1 and opening snap
Symptom triggers: Tachycardia, pregnancy, fever (decrease diastolic filling time)
Intervention: PMBC (percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy) for favorable anatomy
content.statement: Mitral stenosis creates obstruction to left atrial emptying, causing pulmonary congestion and atrial fibrillation, managed with rate control, anticoagulation, and percutaneous or surgical intervention for severe symptomatic disease.

explanation.intuition: Think of mitral stenosis as a narrowed doorway between the left atrium and ventricle. When the door can't open fully, traffic backs up - the atrium enlarges, pressure builds, and congestion spills back into the lungs. Anything that speeds up the heart (exercise, fever, pregnancy) worsens symptoms because there's less time for blood to squeeze through the narrow opening during diastole.
explanation.key_insight: MS is uniquely pressure-dependent on DIASTOLIC TIME. Unlike other valvular lesions where systolic function dominates, MS symptoms worsen with tachycardia because shortened diastole limits LA emptying. Rate control is therefore CRITICAL - beta-blockers to slow heart rate and lengthen diastole.
explanation.technical_details: Mitral valve area can be calculated by pressure half-time (MVA = 220/PHT) or planimetry. Wilkins score (0-16) grades leaflet mobility, thickening, calcification, and subvalvular involvement - score ≤8 predicts good PMBC outcome. Mean gradient >5-10 mmHg and PASP >50 mmHg indicate hemodynamic significance.

definitions_glossary.mitral_stenosis: Narrowing of mitral valve orifice obstructing diastolic LV filling
definitions_glossary.rheumatic_heart_disease: Valvular damage from autoimmune response to group A streptococcus
definitions_glossary.mitral_valve_area: Cross-sectional area of mitral orifice; normal 4-6 cm²
definitions_glossary.pressure_half_time: Time for transmitral gradient to decrease by half; used to calculate MVA
definitions_glossary.opening_snap: High-pitched early diastolic sound from stenotic mitral valve opening
definitions_glossary.LA_enlargement: Left atrial dilation from chronic pressure overload
definitions_glossary.PMBC: Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy - catheter-based intervention
definitions_glossary.Wilkins_score: Echocardiographic scoring system predicting PMBC success (≤8 favorable)
definitions_glossary.commissure: Junction between anterior and posterior mitral leaflets; fused in rheumatic MS
definitions_glossary.pulmonary_hypertension: Elevated pulmonary artery pressure from transmitted LA pressure
definitions_glossary.ortner_syndrome: Hoarseness from left recurrent laryngeal nerve compression by enlarged LA
definitions_glossary.hemoptysis: Coughing blood from pulmonary venous hypertension; rupture of bronchial veins

pathophysiology.mechanism: Fixed obstruction to LV filling during diastole causes LA pressure elevation, pulmonary venous hypertension, and ultimately right heart failure

rheumatic.mechanism: Molecular mimicry → autoimmune inflammation → commissural fusion, leaflet thickening
rheumatic.epidemiology: Still most common cause globally; rare in developed countries

degenerative.mechanism: Mitral annular calcification extending to leaflets

hemodynamic_consequences: LA pressure elevation → pulmonary venous congestion → dyspnea
LA enlargement → atrial fibrillation → loss of atrial kick → hemodynamic decompensation
Pulmonary hypertension → RV failure → peripheral edema, hepatomegaly

physical_examination: Loud S1 (mobile calcified valve snapping closed)
Opening snap after S2 (closer to S2 = more severe)
Low-pitched diastolic rumble at apex with presystolic accentuation (if sinus rhythm)
Signs of RHF in advanced disease

diagnostic_testing.echo: Gold standard; assess MVA, gradient, LA size, PASP, valve morphology (Wilkins score)
diagnostic_testing.ECG: LA enlargement (P mitrale), AF, RVH in advanced
diagnostic_testing.CXR: LA enlargement, straightening of left heart border, pulmonary congestion

medical.rate_control: Beta-blockers or CCBs to prolong diastolic filling time
medical.anticoagulation: All MS patients with AF (even paroxysmal) or prior emboli; consider if LA >55mm

intervention_indications: Symptomatic severe MS (MVA ≤1.5 cm²) despite medical therapy
Asymptomatic severe MS with PASP >50 mmHg at rest or >60 with exercise
Symptomatic moderate MS with exercise hemodynamics

PMBC.criteria: Favorable anatomy (Wilkins ≤8), no significant MR, no LA thrombus

surgery.commissurotomy: Open surgical option if PMBC not feasible
surgery.MVR: Mitral valve replacement for severely calcified/distorted valves

definition.@value: A valvular heart disease characterized by narrowing of the mitral valve orifice, obstructing blood flow from the left atrium to left ventricle during diastole

scopeNote.@value: Covers etiology, hemodynamics, diagnosis, and treatment of mitral stenosis

learning_objectives: Describe the pathophysiology of mitral stenosis and its hemodynamic consequences
Classify mitral stenosis severity by valve area and mean gradient
Recognize physical examination findings including opening snap and diastolic rumble
Explain why rate control is critical in MS management
Identify candidates for PMBC based on Wilkins score
clinical_pearls: Loud S1 + opening snap + diastolic rumble = classic MS triad
Shorter S2-OS interval = more severe MS (higher LA pressure)
Anticoagulate ALL MS patients with any AF - high stroke risk
Pregnancy increases blood volume and HR - can decompensate MS
Wilkins score ≤8 predicts good PMBC outcome
common_misconceptions: MS causes systolic murmur - it's a diastolic rumble
All MS is rheumatic - degenerative/calcific increasing in developed countries
Symptoms correlate directly with valve area - tachycardia and other factors important
